intro: Scrophularia canina var. ramosissima, commonly known as dog's mouth, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring erect, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of tubular, pink to purple flowers that bloom from June to August. Its leaves are lance-shaped, often with a slightly hairy surface, and are arranged oppositely along the stem. It prefers sunny to partially shaded locations in well-drained soils.
